content: Is it possible that they are sent to Junk by your mail server, before Thunderbird retrieves it? Maybe you could consider turning off your mail service's spam filtering, if possible.
creator: rednoise

content:
None of the filters would make the messages disappear immediately. If the filter action is Delete, they would be sent to Trash, and they would stay there for a while. Have you checked there?

Disable all your filters and see if the situation resolves.

Examine each filter to see if you can find the culprit.

You can enable the Filter Log - that might help find the bad filter.
creator: rednoise

creator: ianwinick

content: Was the old account an IMAP account? If so, whatever is still on PC may be just remnants (headers without content), as the full messages would be on the now unavailable server. If the old account was POP, all messages can be copied by exiting thunderbird and copying from within profile folder under the Mail\<POPaccount> folder. My guess is that your account was IMAP, in which case you may not be able to salvage all messages due to the server switch.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks, David.

Yes, it was an IMAP account. And yes, when I open up mails in the folders that won't copy, there is nothing there. Other ones are fine, though - any idea why that is?

All the best


Ian
creator: ianwinick

content: IMAP accounts sync to the server. If an IMAP account attempts to open but the server isn't there, the content on PC is stripped as that is part of syncing to server. That isn't Thunderbird, it's IMAP. If you think some of the folders have content, your only way to salvage is to exit thunderbird and copy with windows file explorer and place in the Mail\Local Folders folder, restart thunderbird and then check for content. Attempting to check from within a nonexistent IMAP account may cause whatever is there to be deleted.
creator: davidsk

content: You need to log into your online account to change the password.

creator: @next

content:
In quale posizione le crei? Che dimensione ha il tuo archivio di posta? Hai spazio su disco?

Inoltre, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: Please provide more information on your problem, plus any error messages (in English). Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: If you copied the thunderbird folder, then both profiles will be there. click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll to 'profile folder' click 'about:profile', highlight the desired profile and launch it. (These steps apply to Windows versions, and I am not sure they are identical for Macs.)
creator: davidsk

content: I am assuming the tablet will be IMAP. If so, a trash folder on IMAP is not accessible from POP account. I suggest creating a folder on the IMAP acccount, moving important messages there and, on returning home, move those messages back to inbox prior to using the POP account.
creator: davidsk
